author: mklement0
body:
Currently, there is no way to learn of the path-separator character(s) that must be used to separate the components of a path for a given provider, because `[System.Management.Automation.ProviderInfo]`, as returned by `Get-PSProvider`, has no such property.

In the absence of such information, users may be tempted to assume that `\` and `/` can be universally - and interchangeably - used, which is _not necessarily_ true; for instance, the registry provider only properly supports `\`, given that `/` is a valid char. in registry key names - see #5536

Future providers - or even existing third-party providers - could conceivably use completely different characters (of necessity).

Adding a `[string[]]`-typed `.PathSeparator` property to `[System.Management.Automation.ProviderInfo]` would help.

Additional considerations:

* Non-hierarchical providers such as the `Variable` and `Function` providers have no real need for a path separator: e.g., `Get-Item variable:PSHome` works just fine. In practice, these providers follow the `FileSystem` provider's example and allow interchangeable use of `/` and `\`, and  tab completion even explicitly inserts these optional chars.: `/` on Unix, and `\` on Windows.

* Third-party implementers of providers will need to provide appropriate values for `.PathSeparator` too.

* The name to give this new property is debatable, given that the .NET framework has already sown confusion around `[System.IO.Path]::DirectorySeparator` (the path-_component_ separator) vs. `[System.IO.Path]::PathSeparator` (the path-_environment-variable-entry_ separator). However, given that the term _directory_ is filesystem-specific and we're talking about abstractions here, my vote is still for `.PathSeparator`.

Desired behavior
------------------

```powershell
> Get-PSProvider FileSystem | % PathSeparator
\
/

> Get-PSProvider Registry | % PathSeparator
\
```

Environment data
----------------

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```powershell
PowerShell Core v6.0.0-rc
```

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
>  given that the term directory is filesystem-specific and we're talking about abstractions here, my vote is still for .PathSeparator.

My first look was on FileSystem provider and the name confused me. It will always confuse users in the context. So I think we need another abstraction name.
We use `New-Item` for all providers and `Item` corresponds "item of path" in FileSystem provider. I'd expect that .Net Core [System.IO.Path]::PathSeparator transforms to ItemSeparator.
On the other hand, we have Join-Path. If we had a PathSeparator parameter there, what would it mean? Again confuse.

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body:
@iSazonov: I'm not sure I understand all your points, but let me try to respond:

>  It will always confuse users in the context. So I think we need another abstraction name.

Why? To me, the confusion stems only from `[System.IO.Path]::PathSeparator`, but I don't think we should worry about that - it's .NET's confusion, not PowerShell's.

Strictly speaking, we're looking for the character that is used to separate item names that are sequenced to form a path - `PathSeparator` seems like the most intuitive choice to me.

I guess `ItemSeparator` would work too, but to me it's preferable to mention the relevant concept in the name: a _path_ [of item names].

> I'd expect that .Net Core `[System.IO.Path]::PathSeparator` transforms to `ItemSeparator`.

`[System.IO.Path]::PathSeparator` has no relationship to providers per se, and shouldn't be reflected there - it's a character used by convention to separate _paths as a whole_ in a _reserved environment variable_ (and, as an aside, is itself a legal filename character on its respective platforms). Whether and where to represent this other separator in PowerShell too is a separate question; my name suggestion would be `PathVariableSeparator`.

> On the other hand, we have `Join-Path`. If we had a `PathSeparator` parameter there, what would it mean? Again confuse.

In line with the new property, it would refer to the separator used to separate item names in a path - where is the confusion?

comments.author: vexx32
comments.body: Agreed with using `PathVariableSeparator` or even something a degree more removed perhaps, like `PathVariableDelimiter` because its function is so completely different to PathSeparator; it's not separating portions of a path, it's usually a character that can't be used in a path at all, so it serves to clearly delimit individual values in the environment variable.

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body:
Thanks, @vexx32, but I suggest sticking with "separator" as the most familiar term (for which "delimiter" is a near-synonym with no clear distinction), because in the abstract the functionality is the same: 

A list or sequence (path)  is formed from entries, and a character is placed between those entries to mark their boundaries.

The entries just happen to be different entities:
* In the case of `$env:PATH`, the entities happen to be filesystem paths themselves (and, as stated, strictly speaking you _can_ use `:` in filesystem paths on Unix, and `;` on Windows, but it's probably a bad idea).
* In the case of a provider path, the entities happen to be item names (file/directory names, in the case of the filesystem provider)

title: [System.Management.Automation.ProviderInfo] (returned by Get-PSProvider) should contain path-separator information
